definition: Embedding imperceptible signals in AI-generated content to enable later identification of synthetic origin

positive_examples: SynthID embeds an invisible watermark in AI-generated images for later detection.
AI watermarking survives common transformations like compression and cropping.
The watermark detector confirmed the image was generated by our model.
Robust AI watermarks enable tracing synthetic content back to its source.
AI watermarking embeds statistical patterns that are invisible but detectable.
The watermark persisted through social media compression and resizing.
AI watermarking enables platforms to identify and label synthetic content.
The detection tool verified the watermark was intact in the shared image.
AI watermarking provides a cryptographic link between content and generator.
The watermark enabled identifying which model and user generated the content.
training_hints.disambiguation: Invisible cryptographic marking of AI content, not visible watermarks or labels

opposite_reasoning: UnmarkedContent provides the strongest opposition for Fisher-LDA purposes because it represents the clearest binary distinction: content with embedded identification signals vs content without. This creates maximum separability in the feature space. While ContentAuthentication is conceptually rich for AI safety, UnmarkedContent offers a cleaner negative anchor - it represents the absence of the defining property (watermarking), making it ideal for μ- in w ≈ μ+ - μ-. This opposition is useful for steering away from watermarking processes toward unmarked/natural content states.
